titleInfo.title: Looking Inward
titleInfo.subTitle: Identifying the Local within the Global in Late Fifteenth-Century Sevillian Artworks

mods:mods.abstract: The Iberian city of Seville offers a case study of motif and iconographic transference in the late Middle Ages and Early Modern era. Previous scholars have addressed the idea of transference through a formal lens without consideration for the cultural and historical contexts that surround it, and have previously noted, though rarely explicated, a Sevillian school of painting. The limited foundational studies on late fifteenth- and early sixteenth-century artworks in Seville, most published in the early twentieth century, focus on stylistic categorization and the indiscriminate application of terms such as Hispano-Flemish and mudéjar. My dissertation nuances these terms through an investigation of the artworks' place and development in a Sevillian context, specifically parsing local and global stylistic and iconographic influences apparent in the works. My work addresses the local outside of the simple framework of mudéjar, the stylistic qualification meant to designate ornamentation, architecture, and motifs showing Islamic stylistic influence but created within a Christian Iberian context. A close study of how prints and printing in general functioned in Seville and Granada clarifies how iconographies were transferred across media as well as how specific motifs were deployed in efforts to convert Muslims and Jews. While many prints do not survive, my dissertation reconstructs how they were employed by the citizens of Seville. The function and purpose of prints varied significantly: many were kept in the home and used for personal devotion by so-called Old Christians; they were distributed to non-Christians and new converts, and helped to prevent accusations of apostasy; and they served as models for painted and carved panel compositions. Additionally, terminology like "mudéjar" does not work for a Sevillian context where Islamic decorative motifs were strongly connected to the culture and history of the city. Tracking how, when, and why these motifs were copied and transferred sheds light on the global function of Iberian artworks and provides insight into how these methods operated more broadly. My research highlights connectivity and diversity in a way that impacts current studies and modern understandings of how we can define globality in the Middle Ages.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Art History in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Erika Loic, Professor Directing Dissertation; Keith Howard, University Representative; Stephanie Leitch, Committee Member; Paul Niell, Committee Member.
